Albeit a fine effort, I found the book leaving me with more questions than answers. I think when pondering the universe and what makes it work - this is a good thing. The first two chapters are fascinating and a must read for anyone interested in the who's who of physics and cosmology. By the author's own admission the book attempts to avoid the use of mathematics and equations in fear of losing a general audience. The truth however is there are times when a little more detailed background information would have helped illustrate the point. The book is not suitable for midnight reading as it requires some intense and critical thought regardless of its attempt to appeal to the non-PHD type. I recommend the book over the tapes in that the book allows easy access between pages and chapters. Re-reading here is a necessity, not an option. Trying to 'get it' while fighting traffic will leave you exhausted ... hardly the way to start work! Enjoy. WCC.

Armed with a high school knowledge of physics, I decided to try this book, to see what all the hype was about.  Heard alot of good reviews of it, and rightly so.  I could follow the topics and theories discussed and was amazed at the concepts.  While I had some vague understanding of some of the theories, this certainly shows how little I actually understood.  Hawkings is brilliant, just in dummying up these concepts and relaying them as something so simple, shows his immence mental prowess.  It's a real joy to learn these things that you've read about and basically just ignored because you thought they were so complex.  Granted that he has simplified things but still the basis is there.  Here is a rare man who understands science and people, and can incite us to learn. Just fascinating, makes me want to read more about science, not just the fiction stuff either.

Before reading this book, I had heard much about how Stephen Hawking is one of the most, if not the most brilliant mind living today. This book is without a doubt proof, as he gracefully is able to bring such massively  complex topics into understandable terms for virtually anyone willing to  play with the ideas to understand. I expected a voyage through difficult  material, but i was pleasantly suprised by the good style of the writing  and the appropriate interjections of opinion that accompanied it. Gradually  as we move through time with the book the material gets more complicated,  but try and understand these concepts anywhere else unless you have a firm  foundation in physics. This is a literary monument, and a throughly  enjoyable and satisfying trip through modern physics. Refreshing in its  approach, enlighting with its delivery of the content.
Great book.  It took a while to get to what I bought the book for.  I got the same answer searching the net in about 2 minutes.

book that sold millions of copies and one wonders how many people read it and of those, how many actually understood it all. I have a scientific education (chemistry), but I frankly admit I did not get it all. It is difficult to explain what is in the book, but is in essence about where we came from and what we are heading to with regard to the universe, time, space and matter. The book is very well written, with a sense of humor and trying to explain the nearly inexplicable to the layman; I could follow large chunks of the text, but sometimes it is just too difficult to comprehend. This made me think: is Stephen Hawking's disadvantage (being locked up in his own body) also his disadvantage? He probably has more time than most people to turn into himself and contemplate on such extremely complex items as black holes, wormholes and the (in)finity of the universe. A book that leaves you in awe.
amazingly well written & illustrated. even someone like me, with no college education, could follow & understand it.

I picked up this book because I didn't know anything about space, other than watching Star Trek and Battlestar Galactica.  All I knew was I WANT all of that to be real, I love the idea of space travel, aliens, etc. and I wanted to know where we are really at in terms of discovering all of this.  This book is amazingly well written.  Hawking does a great job of explaining really complicated science in straightforward terms.  It's still challenging, and not "light" reading, but fascinating stuff.  It left me feeling in total awe of the universe we live in, and humbled, actually, to know that somehow humanity came about from these random (or not? depends on if you believe in God) collisions of stars and heating/cooling of elements...I think everyone should read this book.
Stephen Hawking wrote a very good that is easy for me to read n explains many open questions that I have.
an outstanding effort to make a complicated but interesting subject understandable to the average reader.

When I first picked up this book, I expected much more. Hawking uses simple language to explain extremely complicated theories (relativity, uncertainty principle, quantum mechanics, GUTs) and I applaud the absense  of mathematical equations (except one, E=mc^2). However, in my opinion,  Hawking's explanations on some key cosmological points are sometimes too  concise, whereas on the other hand too much time is spent on other topics  such as particle theory. This book did not captivate me as much as it  should have, despite reading it twice.

A Brief History Of Time sums up all the universe's time into one complete book. It goes all the way from the big bang, to where future theories come into play. Hawking does a great job explaining older theories and also telling why they were wrong or proven incorrect. Then he also tells of his work about black holes and his search for the ultimate theory of the universe. Many of the complex equations are shown in pictures and examples that are easy to follow. This book is for anyone interested in space travel, black holes, or anything of the sort.
Epic piece!  Hawking is quite the dude.  Brilliant mind with a great sense of humour and irony.
Revisiting an old friend in this book good reading, updated and book is in great condition.

This is a must read for anyone interested in figuring out how it all works.  Do not be worried that the ideas presented in this book are to complex for anyone less than a physics major to grasp.  I found that it was  a fairly easy read with only one or two of the concepts in it to too hard  for me to grasp, and I have not even taken physics in school yet (I am only  a freshman in highschool).  Hawkings clearly explains his ideas by using  metaphors from everyday life.  Trust me: if you want to know how things  came to be, and how they might end, then this is the book for you.

Super easy read, easy to follow, and the perfect length. With other books of this genre, I've often found authors to be very long-winded. I appreciate that explanations are given with one or two relevant, well-thought-out examples, and then the text progresses forward. The writing style was very easy to follow--it had a nice flow that moved the reader easily from subject matter to subject matter without getting too tangled or rambling. I am looking forward to reading his other works in the coming months (I have a Brian Greene that I am struggling to finish first). All-in-all, I would recommend this for anyone who is interested in physics or cosmology.

After studying the Theory of Relativity and Quantum Theory in my high school physics class, I decided to take it one step further. My teacher recommended it as a good introduction. It was actually a great introduction to theoretical physics. Time travel and worm holes all seemed like science fiction, but Hawking showed (without the use of advanced mathematics) that these concepts are scientific possibilities, theoretically speaking. I recomend this book to anyone who questions the nature and origin of the universe.

This is a fantastic little book for those who are interested in physics but maybe not quite enough to read something more dense. I found it easy to read, easy to understand, and very light in the information it provides. If you (like me) are the type of person who loves science and wants to know every detail, you're going to find yourself asking "Why?" quite often because Hawking keeps it simple. That said, this isn't a textbook and I knew going into it that I would still have questions; if anything it made me even more curious about physics and has driven me to learn more!

An excellent overview of the cosmology of the universe.  Although I am many years removed from the classroom, I found most of the concepts understandable.  The only difficulty is the complication of particles with various spins. The discussion of the four forces was very insightful.  I certainly subscribe to the anthropic principle as a Christian and found nothing to sway me away from that belief.  I had always wanted to read this book but never got around to it.  The movie "The Theory of Everything" made me want to finally make the plunge.  It wass well worth it.

I loved this one. Hawking does a pretty good job of speaking intelligently on the nature of the universe and some some pretty advanced particle physics, but manages do to do so while keeping it at a level you do not need to be a rocket scientist, or any other kind of scientist, to follow along. Certainly many of his thoughts are conjecture and subject to further disproval by advancements in science, technology and research, but I dont know that any discoveries will totally invalidate his conclusions, just potentially put a finer tip on some of his fuzzier theories.

This book doesn't NEED another good review, but here's mine. Professor Hawking has long been a hero of mine and this book is just another reason why. He finds easy to understand analogies and ways to describe the inner workings of the universe. I am no scientist or even a great scholar, but I was able to easily understand about 95% of this book. There were of course areas I wish I had more knowledge (particularly particle physics) but even so I feel I have gained a great understanding of the forces driving our universe into existence and shaping it even today.

First of all, i was disappointed that the cover was not the one shown in the description.  However, the book itself is amazing.  I'm a self-taught physicist and I thought this book would be mostly things I already knew, but it is at once very simple and very in-depth.  While most science programs deem it unnecessary to teach you thing such as what "spin" or "color" of a particle means, this book make it very clear.  Hawking has an amazing talent; not just for discovering truths about our universe, but also making those truths available to lay persons.

A Brief History of Time was written by Stephen Hawking, one of the most brilliant physicists ever known, and he helps the common man to comprehend the unfathomable concepts of the universe. The best aspect of this book is that, even the most scientific theory is explained to us in a very uncomplicated style. It's truly commendable that he includes God as he rightly says "the reward of understanding the universe may be a glimpse of `the mind of God'."

This great book I read years ago. Hawkin being an internationally acclaimed scientists has used the best of his knowledge and skill in this book. Besides, he has precisely depicted a brief history of science too. This combination of history and science has made this book exceptional. I have read his recent book also that is not that interesting. One aspect fascinated me much that was description of solar system and the thought of ancient people about the rotation of the earth. Moreover this book questions the Holy Bible.

Very thought provoking, although the presumption that contraction means negative entropy and a reversal of the time arrow makes no sense to me.  Contraction can be just as disorganized as expansion and would not follow the same path back to the singularity unless the universe is elastic and has the memory of a rubber band that returns to it's original form after being stretched.  I suspect it would end up like a crumpled ball of plastic wrap and be less organized and just as entropic as when it was under expansion.

Following the excellent current movie on his life, A Theory of Everything, I decided to give a Brief History of Time a second reading after 15 years. On the first reading I understood perhaps 50% of it, this time I got around 80% - the section on up and down and colored Quarks still eluded me. Otherwise this is a relatively brief and succinct analysis of our current thinking about the universe and is a rewarding read.  Hawking's sense of humor shines through.

How can a subject apparently so heavy, be explained with such understanding of other peoples minds? I guess it`s not so difficult to explain the mysteries of the universe for someone that knows what they are talking about, but an 18 year old, female student (me) got alot out of the book. I read that it`s been sold one copy per 750 people in this world. I can definately understand that!! Thanks you for "listening".... Yours sincerely Margit Dyrland
The book that started it all! Why don't you already own this?

Way to hard for me to comprehend at first, but after I slowed down my reading pace and tried to learn the big words ,anything over five letters , it became hard to put down. WOW,,, what a mind . After every page all I could say is ," wow , what did I just read?. " It seems like the  last couple of chapters got easier to read , almost like somebody else wrote them.  It definitely is worth reading , even if you don't , like me , understand a word of it.

Most people who read this book (such as me) will probably only manage to understand _properly_ about two words, namely "Hawking" and "Steven"... but understanding in this case is not really necessary. This is an adventure into the world of physics and, somehow, it manages to be a thrilling one. Full credit to Hawking for this; he draws the reader in, grabs them tight by the collar, and takes them on an eye-opening ride. Unmissable!

I have to say I have been a fan of Mr. Hawking ever since I first saw in Star Trek: Next Gen and enjoyed his television show Stephen Hawking's Universe. This book does an excellent job explains the aspects of modern physics in a simple yet interesting way. This along with some excellent humor and very well done diagrams really help to make every much easier to understand. A must read for anyone who has ever asked how does the world we live in work.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book and would suggest it to anyone who is interested in knowing how the universe works and the steps that brought science to the current understanding of today. While many of the concepts are complicated, Hawking does a great job of explaining them so that a PhD. in physics is not required. Be prepared to go on an adventure through time and space to try and find the ultimate theory of the universe that explains it all!

the brilliant thing about this book is that he writes about what scientists believe, and why they believe it, while still somehow totally respecting the world of religious beliefs. I think that is one of the secrets to this book.  He is so polite in not buying into the "science vs religion" debate.  He takes complex concepts and explains them in as simple a way as he can, so that the laymen may at least have a glimmer of understanding.

This book is a good overview of the theories behind the big bang, the expansion of the universe, and physics in general.  Hawking explains these ideas in a very clear-cut, easy-to-understand way, making the book easier to read than one might think.  I would highly recommend this book to anyone who doesn't have a background in physics or astronomy but wants to know something about what scientists currently think about our universe.

For those of you who can't unlock the power of physics, this book is the key.  This is perhaps one of the most insightful books on physics ever published.  It is simple to understand, and it will make you re-consider everything you once thought you understood.  Simply put: "Wow!"

Even though it seems to be advertised for the "layman", it's still pretty deep in parts. Some sections a pretty far out there in terms of being able to picture" concepts described...even for someone with 8 years of college ---with physics, cosmology and mathematics courses. It is thought provoked, provides some surprising "theoretics". I have to say I'm only half way through but would still recommend.

Hawking does a great job presenting several obscure concepts of physics and astronomy in a way that most people can understand.  Because these concepts are so far outside everyday phenomena they can be quite fascinating.  This book is a great read for anyone with a passing interest in physics or astronomy with or without a degree in those areas.  I definitely advocate at least checking the book out for nearly anybody.

If you have an interest in physics, heard of concepts seemingly beyond your grasp, and don't need to know all the equations, this book is for you.  You will discover what those concepts really are and how they came about. You get to read it in plain language with a bit of humor when you least expect it.  The biggest question you may have after reading this book will be "Why did I wait so long to read this?"

I treasure this book as it gives a fascinating introduction to the cutting edge theoritical physics of the day.  It makes one realise how a falsehood can be easily dressed up in the clothe of high altar science and passed on as absolute truth.  I am talking about the Big Bang theory, mind you.  Any one who studies the philosophy of metaphysics should understand origin of that falsehood.  It is a big con!

Hawking has a way of his words, he can take the most complicated thing and make it as simple as it can be. Within the book he asks the question "Did the universe have a beginning, and if so, what happened before then"? The question really gets you thinking, since everything has to have a beginning and an end, but since space is everything, what could have been here before...? The book is great!

Definitely worth reading in Dr. Hawking's inimitable style.  Makes basic theoretical physics understandable to those who studied other subjects (or who struggled w. physics in college)!  To be honest, I mostly bought the book because I'd recently seen "The Theory of Everything" and they go together well.  The man's clearly a genius and generous about giving credit to those who came before him.

This book can enlighten any person who has the ability to grasp basic mathematical and scientific subjects without leaving you behind with 6-syllable words or latin definitions meant for phd's. I personally recommend this book for anyone who enjoys broadening their understanding of science, the world, and more expansively...the universe. Great read and must have for any scientific library.

Surprisingly clear in his descriptions of very complicated theories, it was one of those books I persisted in finishing even though some of the discussion was well beyond me.  I clearly did not understand every word, although it seems Stephen Hawking tried very hard to make it understandable.  I did learn quite a lot about the various theories of time and space and am glad I read it.

This is the last book I thought I'd read.  No doubt Stephen Hawking is a brilliant man but I like to relax with something light and easy to read.  "A Brief History Of Time" is an EXCELLENT book and written in language that a lay person can understand.  He is an exceptional  and sensitive human being and has led a remarkable life. Now I am eager to see the movie.  Well done!

I am so happy I bought this book. Each word painstakingly written with his cheek movements make up this absolutely stunning masterpiece of the current big Scientific Ideas and theories. He is able to bring his brilliant mind down to the reader's level with concise points and clear explanations. You won't go wrong with this book if you are interested physics, astronomy or cosmology.

First released in 1988 this fantastic cassette settles all arguments about the musical antecedents of the All Your Bases rave phenomenon. This remastered and re-engineered classic benefits enormously from Talvin Singh's deft touch in the studio and Professor Roger Penrose's innovative remixing of several of Stephen Hawking's central equations. Old favourites such as "Big Bang to Big Crunch - Singularity to Singularity" are still here, but revised thinking on non-baryonic particles is reflected, in the case of the above track, with a fresh UK Garage rub surely not foreseen by the astrophysicist when he first started experimenting with Newtonian general relativity and quantum mechanics back in the day. Hawking's freestyling with Roots Manuva on provides a competent (if inevitable) concession to hip-hop - think "Dusted" jacked up with an almost ironic take on string theory. But the Cambridge Lucasian Professor of Mathematics is at his best when he lays down his trademark dub-saturated beats as in "The Role of Weakly Interacting Cold Particles" with Sons of Silence and Professor Alexander Valenkin and the Tufts University Particle Fizzix Boyz taking the 'nuff respects on the sleeve notes.
Great read and hard to put down. I love this book.

While I may be too dumb to understand some of the concepts, I don't blame that on the writing at all. The concepts are put forward as succinctly and as simply as possible without losing the "meat" of the actual information. While I think it'll take a couple of reads to really get a good handle on this stuff (at least for me), I have really enjoyed this book so far.

Stephen Hawking is truly one of the most intelligent, cogent, readable scientists ever born. This book explains in a very understandable way, the way this universe could have (probably was) been formed, all without a single reference to a divine creator, with no disrespect for the divine, simple devoid of the need to attribute (or blame) a divine power for everything!

If you think you are not interested in science, think again.  Hawking's mind is able to present theoretical, complex thought into understandable, fascinating reading.  If you saw the movie, "The Theory of Everything", though it was only a "brief" look at Hawking's life you may have some idea of how remarkable he is.  The book should be read by all.
Fascinating!
Must read one
Very good!  I have to read it again to understand all of it,but I feel it is great!

Stephen Hawking makes quantum physics understandable and interesting for an educated lay person. He makes comparisons and visuals that help understand the complex. worth reading if you seek thoughts on how life works.

I will not even try and claim that I understood everything that Stephen Hawking presented in his book, I'm nowhere near that smart. I do understand much more about the universe and what makes it tick than I did before I read this book. Thank you Mr. Hawking for putting out the effort to make a complex problem into something much more understandable.
This was such an interesting book and though I studied science I believe anyone could read and enjoy it without worrying about too much jargon
Stephen Hawking gives us a new insight into the world that we know. How it could have possibly come into being and what could have happened after it came into being.  A true masterpiece indeed.

Before reading this book I had read "A short history of nearly everything" and "Cosmos". This book is a mixture of science history with explanation of scientific concepts. I like the explanation of the uncertainty principle. The latter half of the book is filled with lot of concepts which I could not understand.

Though it's taking me a while to read, I really am enjoying this book.  Though I'm not a scientist by profession, I am learning lots about the work and ideas that seem to inspire those who study time and space.

Hawking's brain most of the time is probably focused like a laser on the core and most difficult issues of cosmological physics. It is much appreciated that he took what must have been a significant portion of his time to prepare this engaging work for the public and even for students of physics like myself, who have not been able to delve into the difficult and complex mathematics required at the forefront of physics these days. Of course, parts of Stephen's exposition were difficult to follow, but so are the amazing concepts leaders in this field find themselves having to propose and work on and try out with their advanced math skills in order to make advances.  I very much appreciate this tiny peak into their world and Prof. Hawking's clear exposition of the essential conclusions experts like himself have been able to make. I only hope that we'll see him write a second edition, catching us all up on the new experimental work and theoretical advances in the field, especially the amazing work being done and discoveries being found from the microwave cosmic background radiation.
this is a book written by stephen hawking about science and that is all that is really needs to be said.

While I admire the writer's command of subjects beyond my schooling, I find myself struggling to understand what he is writing about.  Without question, Hawking is a geniius and I am an ignoramus.  He writes clearly, has an engaging style, but his brainpower leaves me in his dust.  I can almost feel my brain stretching as I try to comprehend his grasp of the uiniverse.  My mental muscles are stretched to the limit.  But I hang in there, hoping somehow to catch up with his thinking.

Really great book for anyone wanting a little more understanding of the world and universe around us. Some parts are too advanced for the average reader (including me), but for the most part it was easy to follow and incredibly engaging and fascinating.

It provides an updated view of the history of the universe, the current status of the big theories of Physics, and the key problems to solve to complete our broad understanding of the universe. All this written with mastery, in a way that helps understanding by non-experts. Be prepare to imaginary time going in circles, to matter and antimatter, curved space-time, and so many other concepts that would make you reconsider your role in the universe, as we know it.
A book to keep an read again. Much information that is hard to fully grasp in one reading. The ideas and science presented were interesting and makes me want to learn more.
I found this book to be enjoyable but could only read one or two chapters at one time. I have found the second edition, A Briefer History of Time to be easier to read and understand.

A good long read, requiring concentration. I'll have to read again - at least two more times - to get my head around some of  the concepts. I found it extremely interesting and fascinating, and I'm sure that I will discover more to think about on a second and even a third reading. I think that I might just get the second book that he wrote (a simpler brief history &c.;, &c.;)
I just started reading this.  I was very excited to receive the book.  I cannot imagine it would be anything less than brilliant!
Thoroughly enjoyed "A Brief History of Time" the first time through and will read again soon.  Hawking is brilliant and entertaining.

I bought this book because in Charles Krauthammer's book "Things That Matter", he said he had read it twice. I take my hat off to him if he only needed 2 times to understand what the author was saying. Since I enjoyed C.K.'s book so much, I will try to slug through it a couple of more times. If you want to know how much we don't know about the origin of the universe, this book is for you although it lacks not in theory. If you are mathematically challenged this book is not for you. If watching the old TV series "Numbers" made your head spin, you can figure this guy wrote all the technical dialogue. I am a avid reader. i gave this 3 stars because once in a while you should read something that stretches your mind. It also gave me some insight to the mind of Mr. Krauthammer whose recommendation caused me to read this book. I think it may take a few more than 2 readings for me though. This book is definitely not a page turner but it does fit in with a project I am presently researching. If you are just a casual reader who doesn't enjoy having your limits stretched, this is not for you. But if you enjoy the challenges of calculus and other advanced math theories give it a shot.
It's hard to totally get your mind around all the concepts presented but it's fun to read.  I don't advise reading this before bed since it will fill your mind with ideas and make it hard to sleep.
It was very comprehensive and relatively easy reading considering the depth and complexity of the subject. Prepare for a new aspect on the universe.

Although well written, this is not an easy read -- unless perhaps you are physics enthusiast.  The information about Hawking and the universe were fascinating.  I just had to take it in a sip at a time.

For an amazingly popular book, A Brief History of Time was oddly unsubstantiated. The book is a whirlwind cacophony of ideas - and the reader is left spread but without much depth. Science needs depth for it to be relevant, such books that emphasize breadth come across as drama.
I finally am able to connect loose dots of many physicas principles learned in college. They are all for simple purposes!
For a very smart man, Stephen Hawking writes clearly and concisely, so anyone can understand the intricacies of the science of the universe.
Not in total agreement with his theory that there was no beginning of time and that something or someone created it all.

Hawking's own story is only very indirectly woven into this discussion of the fundamental question of how the world began.  But his own story and personality does lend a special interest to the fascinating ideas that have emerged in the last ~100 years to shed light on this question.
totally absorbing with humor, humanity and thoughtfulness for one wanting to know more about your universal environment. it,s very readable.
Ah per chance to look inside the mind of a great man.  It's a remarkable opportunity that truly humbles you.
Often..... a bit out of my range,  but always a treat to be a part of the world's greatest mind.

I am glad I read this book and I learned more about the expanding universe and sub atomic particles. Parts of the book delved too deeply into very complex issues that I could not comprehend which is why I rated the book three stars

A good introduction for the layman of recent developments in physics and some of the issues these new directions may lead us.  Over all an honest effort;  but, far too many assumptions based upon speculation.  To be fair though, while I enjoyed the ride, the book (unlike the author) suggests a unified theory is a long way from realization.  I had to smile when toward the books end, the question was finally raised, ever so briefly, as to whether any unified theory would accomplish much or serve well.  Finally, I must have completely missed the justification for trying to apply Q. M., a theory predicated upon small particles, when there is no way to speculate about what the big bang was before the bang.
Excellent book.  Very good history of physics with provocative, lucid and entertaining explanations of the most recent theoretical work. A must read.

Stephen Hawking writes in depth to an audience of normal people.  The ending gets a bit deep but is quite understandable in the general sense, considering that there are probably very few who truly understand his work in depth.  It is really good to have at least a bit of a handle on the current direction of the unification of the general theory of relativity.

Bought this book after watching a documentary on PBS about the author. the content is a lot like your school physics class only better organized. I love reading books that are based on real facts and that teach me something!

Very interesting but challenging at the same time.  Dr Hawking has a gift of presenting complicated information in a  clear way, appealing to physicists as well as professionals in other fields of science.

Hawking writes with a voice anyone can understand, even as they unsuccessfully attempt the daunting task of visualizing objects (or even particles...or is that waves?) moving through four dimensional space-time. The chapter on string theory is unfortunately beyond me, but what I could, vaguely, understand was interesting, even entertaining, as was the book as a whole.

Stephen Hawking has overcome a debilitating illness, unable to speak. confined to a wheelchair, his his absolute mastery of physics makes his message clear and easy to follow. Every one who has an interest in physics or indeed the secrets of the universe should get a copy of this book.
It is science about time and the universe not just based on formulae,  reasonably easy to understand.  There doesn't need to be god to start things off - that's the hard part to understand.
I don't know how this was such a best seller. Far too technical for me to understand and I am better educated in this field than the vast majority of people

This is certainly not light, entertaining reading. It is still a monumental effort by one of the greatest minds of our time. There were parts that I honestly did not understand, but that is not the book's fault! I came away with some wonderful knowledge and interesting questions. It's not for everybody, but it is a great book for those of us with inquiring minds.

Stephan Hawking is a very talented mind. The book is written in such a way that most normal people with a little technical knowledge can understand. A light read for those who've studied physics in University without any real new content. I personally would have liked a little more detail but then this book wouldn't be so accessible to read!
This is Hawking explaining complicated concepts to anyone  really motivated enough topay attention and, at the same time, demonstrating the potential of human courage and dedication.
I appreciate the grand theory of this text and its simple explanations of complex problems. Highly recommended for anyone seeking answers past god created it.

For once, these theoretical physicists don't tell us what initiated the big bang in the first place. Where did the material that exploded came from? I cannot understand why they say the black hole doesn't allow anything to escape when at the same time, it jets out a stream of light thousands of light years across the universe.

I bought this book to read before I go to bed, but it's so interesting I stay up all night reading it! It's a real page-turner. If you've ever had a question about the universe, this book will have the answer!

A difficult subject introduced and explained with easily understood examples and analogies. A good historical presentation of the progress of thinking on this subject from the ancient greeks to the modern physics nobel prize winners. A must read for anyone interested in the current thinking on what we know of the universe we live in, on how it originated and even on forecasts for how it might end.
Many years after it was first published, this book still stands as the best available explanation of what time is and how it is to be understood in physics.
Hawking shares his very in depth knowledge of the universe in ways we can understand. Although a difficult read, it's a must.

This was a book that I had heard about for years, but never decided to read.  I am glad I finally did.  Hawking does a spectacular job of explaining the development of the complex mathematics and physics related to trying to understand the origin of the universe (and the theological questions associated with the origin o the universe).  He provides a good explanation of the progression of the understanding, without getting into the math that very few would understand.  It is well written and helps me get a sense of Stephen Hawking as well. I would recommend this to anyone who wants to ponder he complexity of the universe and our part in it.
This book helps me understand concepts that would otherwise be beyond me.  Hawking does a great job in organizing these concepts in a progressive manner.
Well written, easy to follow and understand. Complex science written for the average reader. Look forward to reading more from the author.

If it is even possible to write an engaging description of the origins of the universe, quantum mechanics and string theory, this text would fulfill that promise. In A Brief History of Time, renowned physicist Stephen Hawking lays out the current theories explaining our universe in simple, relatable and witty prose. The book spans the theories of Aristotle, Galileo and Einstein and culminates with the search for a grand unified theory that would answer the question of how and why we and our universe came to be. It includes fascinating discussions of the nature of time, the forces that govern our universe, and a layout of space-time and of our galaxy behind the simplified version most of us learn in school. Simple diagrams provide welcome aids, although Hawking's unpretentious descriptions and analogies often render them unnecessary. Some of the latter chapters are (perhaps unavoidably) a little dry, but on the whole, A Brief History of Time is a mind-bending and captivating book for anyone who never quite understood quantum physics but still has questions about existence beyond our planet.

Hawking's book "A Brief History of Time" can rightly be termed a publishing phenomenon. But why? It is not particularly well-written, contains some poor English and doesn't answer questions it poses early on. As a popular science book, it compares unfavourably with those of Paul Davies and, as far as the subject matter is concerned, "The Primeval Universe" by Jayant Narlikar covers the material much more lucidly. So what is special about this book? For some reason, which is not identifiable immediately, Hawking has become almost a cult figure. This is surprising since he works in a highly abstract area of physics which is not readily understandable to the layperson, except, possibly, as science fiction. It is also true that Hawking has been portrayed as the greatest British scientist since Newton. But is this true? Unlike the theories of Newton, those of Hawking have not been verified as yet. However, criticism of these theories is, on occasion, stifled. A case in point is provided by the Bekenstein-Hawking expression for the entropy of a black hole. A major objection to this is that it violates the Second Law of Thermodynamics. Papers raising this have appeared in the scientific literature and none has been challenged. However, articles have been rejected for publication purely on the grounds that the end result disagreed with Hawking. This is puzzling but it may lead some to feel that Hawking has achieved a status in popular culture which has influenced his scientific standing. If this is so, it is certainly not his fault but it is not a healthy position for science. In the end, though, the fact remains that this book is a real publishing phenomenon but not one which is justified by its contents.
